column2:
There is currently one reference genome for this virus. However, the number of reference genomes can grow as more sequences become available.
Q2: How many viruses do you have in your database?
A2: Our current database contains 7,850 strains and subtypes.

column3:
The number of sequences depends on the pathogen. For influenza, we have 3 types A and 6 types B strains. If you look at the website (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genomes/), there is a page that lists all the strains for the different subtypes.

column5: The most recent data on influenza was published in the January 2003 issue of Clinical Infectious Diseases. It is estimated that at least 1 million cases of acute respiratory infection are caused by influenza each year, with an associated hospitalization rate of approximately 15% for those under age 65 and a case fatality rate of approximately 0.2%. column6:
There are no known comparative analyses of influenza viruses. However, several genetic analyses have been performed on the 1918 Spanish flu virus and other recent strains.

A2: The number of sequences depends on which virus is being studied. In the case of ebola, we have 1, 000 sequences that contain nucleotide and protein data from multiple isolates. This makes it possible to study mutations and how they affect the virulence of the disease.

column6:
No. The closest relative of the 2014-2016 outbreak is the Lassa virus which is not closely related to any other known viruses. This means that no genetic comparison can be made between the two outbreaks.

column3: There is no standard sequence database that can be used to answer this question. Different databases have different definitions of a sequence and may include some sequences that do not represent the full genome, such as the 5' or 3' ends. column6:
Yes. The HIV-1 and HIV-2 viruses were analyzed in terms of their phylogenetic relationships using the Maximum Likelihood method, as implemented in PAUP*4.0b10 (Swofford 2003). This is not an exhaustive survey of all available data on HIV; however, it does provide some insight into the evolution of these two viruses.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has published a list of the first 4,000 genomes sequenced to date. More than 13,500 have been submitted by researchers around the world.
The first coronavirus genome was sequenced in December 2019 and it is known as SARS-CoV-2 or “coronavirus disease 2019” or COVID-19 for short. This
column3:
The genome sequence data is available at NCBI’s GISAID website, with a total of 1,033,508 complete genome sequences from more than 12,000 sequenced isolates across the world. Of these, 18.9% (194,800) were submitted by researchers in Africa.
